ratings.question_text: Overall, how would you rate the workload of this course in comparison to other Yale courses you have taken?
What is your overall assessment of this course?
Do you expect to use this class for credit toward your major, or toward a pre-professional program?

narratives.question_text: How would you summarize ECON 110 05 for a fellow student? Would you recommend ECON 110 05 to another student? Why or why not?
comments: Take it. Do the reading but don't spend too much time on it--the lectures make it all clear.Don't go to lecture sleep-deprived.

Yes -- it is a good introduction to the CPR. In general, though, I wish that the department made the intro-to-CPR class a two semester thing, with the first semester being the aesthetic and the analytic, and the second semester being the dialectic
DON't take this class unless you are a philsophy major. it is very intense!!!!! don't let the low number of 204 fool you. it should be like philosophy 402 or something.

The Critique of Pure Reason could merit a careers-worth of reading rather than just a semesters-worth, and Professor Vogels deep thinking attests to this fact. However, Phil 204 is a good introduction. I urge you to study the Critique if you want glean ideas that really dont seem outdated about metaphysics and epistemology, and to experience such an impressively architectonic system of arguments. This course demands sustained attention and eagerness. The reading and writing requirements are light, but the thinking requirements are heavier than other philosophy courses Ive taken. This is an excellent course for philosophy students who enjoy deep, close reading and who dont mind that not all of the breakthrough ideas encountered in lecture or on ones own will make it into a paper written for the course. This is largely reading and learning for its own sake.
I would recommend it for those wishing to acquire a basic familiarity with Kant's contribution to Western thought.
